awd_titl_txt: The Deuterium to Hydrogen ratio:   A gateway to new Physics
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Tytler and his team will make new high accuracy measurements, using quasar absorption lines, of the primordial ratio of Deuterium to Hydrogen with the goal of finding new physics beyond the standard model of particle physics. Using a baryon density derived from the WMAP satellite, Big Bang Nucleosynthesis (BBN) for the first time predicts the D/H ratio with no free parameters.  This program will test whether the D/H measurements agree with this prediction, either validating our current understanding of BBN, or uncovering new physics. The D/H measurements could reveal a wide variety of new physics, including new types of particles (sterile neutrinos), a difference in the numbers of neutrinos and antineutrinos, long lived decaying particles and deviations from general relativity. 

The primary broader impact of this proposal is training of undergraduate students in research.

por.por_cntn:
The broad goal of this project was to make new astronomical observations using the ground based telescopes to make measurements that allow others in the theoretical physics community to place constraints on the physical conditions in the universe at the time of Big Bang nucleosynthesis (BBN), when the universe was a few minutes old and the density of matter throughout the universe was similar to that in a star. The specific measurement that we use is the ratio of the number of Deuterium to Hydrogen atoms in the universe, the D/H ratio. Deuterium is a fragile heavy isotope of Hydrogen with one proton and one neutron that was make exclusively in BBN. The amount of D that is made depends on all four fundamental forces, on the rate of expansion of the universe at that time, and on the properties of neutrinos. The rate of expansion is given by the total number of particle species that were relativistic during BBN, and it is sensitive to all species, including any with interactions that are too rare to allow detection on Earth. Changes in any of these from commonly assumed values, values measured on Earth today, would lead to changes in D/H. When we used standard physics, and the baryon density derived from measurements of the cosmic microwave background, we can predict the value of D/H that we should observe with an error of about 1%. The more precise goal of the project then was to make more accurate measurements of the primordial D/H set up in BBN. D/H has often be observed in our Solar System and in our Galaxy, but the values there are significantly changed from the D/H made in BBN because stars turn D into Helium, and essentially all gas near and inside galaxies has been inside one or more stars before being ejected. To observe the primordial D/H unchanged from BBN, we must look in places far removed from stars, places that we see in the absorption along the line of sight to QSOs. We can readily select such places by looking for gas with very amounts of heavy elements that are ejected from stars, an indication that a negligible amount of gas has been inside a star. However, only a few % of such gas shows D because random velocities in the vast majority smear out the Hydrogen absorption to obscure the D.

The project had two main activities; finding new QSOs that fortuitously show Deuterium in absorption, and improving the accuracy of the data calibration and measurements where D was found. Our observations did reveal new places where D could be measured and over several years we were able to accumulate the spectra needed to make new D measurements. The second part of the project, making the high accuracy measurements is most demanding of both time and care. We spent a lot of effort to extract the spectra in the way that our measurements require. We looked for and corrected problems such as wavelength errors, sky subtraction errors and flux calibration errors, all of which can express as hidden systematic errors. As usual in this type of precision measurement, this was a slow process involving many trials and modifications. We also re-examined how to set accurate continuum levels and how to estimate the errors on the D and H column density measurements. We concentrated on making accurate measurements towards two QSOs.

One QSO towards which we measured D/H is especially notable because the D is seen in gas that has ten times less heavy elements than any other place where D has been seen in the past. This is important because the primordial D/H should not depend on the amount of heavy elements in the gas. In contrast, changes in D/H from after BBN, such as changes related to stars, will often correlate with the amount of heavy elements in the gas. The D/H that we measure in the most pristine gas is identical within the errors to that seen towards other QSOs with ten to one hundred times more heavy elements, which indicates that all QSOs are showing the sam...
